chameleon.core.element
Interface Element<E extends Element,P extends Element>

public interface Element<E extends Element,P extends Element>

Element is the top interface for an element of a model. Every element can have a parent and children. Every element can have tags associated with it. They are used to attach additional information to an element without modifying Chameleon. The type of the element (typically the subclass being defined).

The type of the parent of the element.

Method Detail

parent

P parent()
Return the parent element of this element. Null if there is no parent.

parentLink

 parentLink()
Return the object representing the bidirectionallink to the parent of this element. This link is NOT used for elements that are generated! Always use parent() to obtain the parent.

disconnect

void disconnect()
Completely disconnect this element and all children from the parent.

isDerived

boolean isDerived()
Check if this element is derived or not.

Returns:
True if this element is derived, false otherwise.

ancestors

List<Element> ancestors()
Return a list of all ancestors. The direct parent is in front of the list, the furthest ancestor is last.

children

List<? extends Element> children()
Return the direct children of this element. The result will never be null. All elements in the collection will have this element as their parent. Note that there can exist non-child elements that have this element as their parent. The reason is that e.g. not all generic instances of a class can be constructed, so the collection can never be complete anyway. Context elements are also not counted as children, there are merely a help for the lookup algorithms. We only keep references to the lexical children, those that are 'physically' part of the program.

descendants

List<Element> descendants()
Recursively return all children of this element. (The children, and the children of the children,...).

descendants

<T extends Element> List<T> descendants(Class<T> c)
Recursively return all descendants of this element that are of the given type.

descendants

<T extends Element> List<T> descendants(Class<T> c,
                                         predicate)
                                    throws Exception
Recursively return all descendants of this element that are of the given type, and satisfy the given predicate. The only checked exception that occurs will come from the predicate. Use the safe and unsafe variants of this method for convenience.

Throws:
Exception

Parameters:

name - The name to be checked
Returns:

setTag

void setTag(Tag tag,
            String name)
Register the given tag under the given name. If an element was already registered under the given name, that element will be unregistered and its element reference set to null such that the bidirectional association is kept consistent.

Parameters:
tag - The tag to be registered
name - The name under which the given tag must be registered,

removeTag

void removeTag(String name)
Remove the tag registered under the given name.

Parameters:
name - The name of the tag to be removed.

hasTags

boolean hasTags()
Check whether or not this element has tags.

nearestAncestor

<T extends Element> T nearestAncestor(Class<T> c)
Return the nearest ancestor of type T. Null if no such ancestor can be found.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the ancestor to be found
Parameters:
c - The class object of type T (T.class)
Returns:

nearestAncestor

<T extends Element> T nearestAncestor(Class<T> c,
                                       predicate)
                                  throws Exception
Return the nearest ancestor of type T that satifies the given predicate. Null if no such ancestor can be found. The only checked exception that can be thrown comes from the predicate. Use the safe and unsafe variants of this method for convenience.

Type Parameters:
T - The type of the ancestor to be found
Parameters:
c - The class object of type T (T.class)
Returns:
Throws:
Exception

language

Language language()
Return the language of this element. Return null if this element is not connected to a complete model.

language

<T extends Language> T language(Class<T> kind)
                            throws WrongLanguageException
Return the language of this element if it is of the wrong kind. Return null if this element is not connected to a complete model. Throws a WrongLanguageException is the language is not of the correct type.

Throws:
WrongLanguageException

clone

E clone()
Return a deep clone of this element. The returned element has no parent.

Returns:

lexicalLookupStrategy

LookupStrategy lexicalLookupStrategy(Element child)
                                     throws LookupException
Return the lexical context for the given child element. The default behavior is to delegate the search to the parent. If this element declares elements itself, it searches those elements first, and only delegates to the parent if nothing is found.

Parameters:
element - The child element of this element for which the context is requested
Throws:
LookupException

lexicalLookupStrategy

LookupStrategy lexicalLookupStrategy()
                                     throws LookupException
Return the lexical context for this element.

Throws:
LookupException

setUniParent

void setUniParent(P parent)
DO NOT USE THIS METHOD UNLESS YOU REALLY KNOW WHAT YOU ARE DOING!!! This method is used internally for generated elements. They are not part of the model, but need a parent in order to have a context. Unfortunately, Java does not allow me to hide the method.

Parameters:
parent -

properties

 properties()
Return the set of properties of this element. The set consists of the explicitly declared properties, and the default properties for which no corresponding explicitly declared property exists.

defaultProperties

 defaultProperties()
Return the default properties of this element.

declaredProperties

 declaredProperties()
Return a property set representing the properties of this element that are explicitly declared.

is

Ternary is( property)
Check if this type element has the given property. If the given property does not apply directly to this type element, we check if it is implied by the declared properties of this element. If the given property does apply to this type element, we still need to check for conflicts with the declared properties.

Parameters:
property - The property to be verified.

property

 property( mutex)
               throws MetamodelException
Return the property of this element for the given property mutex. The property mutex can be seen as the family of properties that a property belongs to. An example of a property mutex is accessibility.

Parameters:
mutex -
Returns:
Throws:
LookupException
MetamodelException
